column6522: He pulled up, or rather the horse stopped of its own accord, and Trafford looked round.
column6523: He appeared to be alone, amidst the _débris_ of the camp.
column6524: Here and there were signs of life and activity which had ebbed away; a broken wheelbarrow, a rusty pick, shovels bent and twisted, and planks half hidden by the weeds that had grown round them, lay about in dismal confusion.
column6525: The whole place, with its air of desertion, was weird and depressing, and Trafford, in his weary and high-strung condition, could scarcely repress a shudder.
column6526: He wondered why the horse had brought him there, for though he listened intently and looked about him keenly, he could neither see nor hear any sign of the presence of any human being save himself.
column6527: He dismounted, and loosely fastening the bridle to a tree, so that the horse could feed, entered the hut.
column6528: It was in ruins, and looked as if it had been left hastily.
column6529: Trafford half hoped that he might find some remnant of food, but there was nothing of the kind.
column6530: He went down to the stream and got a drink of water, and threw himself down to wait until the horse had rested and he could resume his journey.
column6531: He felt that he would be wise to remain the night there, but the place depressed him, and it seemed to him that he could know no rest until he had found Norman and Esmeralda.
column6532: He lay, with his head upon his hand, watching the horse and still feeling half stupefied, when suddenly he knew that something alive was approaching him.
column6533: It was dusk now, it would soon be dark.
column6534: He peered into the shadow of the bush from whence the sound came, and his hand sought his revolver.
column6535: A moment or two later a tall, well-built figure emerged from the bush and approached the hut, a horse followed at a little distance with drooping head, as if too weary for anything save following in his master’s footsteps.
column6536: Varley, for it was he, walked to the hut and entered.
column6537: He came out a moment afterward, and Trafford, who could now see his face plainly, was struck by its well-bred air as well as by its pallor and the expression of stern resolution which seemed to mask anxiety.
column6538: Varley looked round about him searchingly, then sunk on to the upturned wheelbarrow, sighed, and removing his hat, wiped the perspiration from his brow.
column6539: He had all the appearance of waiting for some one.
column6540: Trafford watched him closely, and he felt convinced that this man was neither a bushranger nor a common digger.
column6541: At this moment Trafford’s horse neighed a greeting to Varley’s, and Varley sprung to his feet.
column6542: Trafford, knowing that concealment was no longer possible, rose and walked toward the hut.
column6543: At the sound of his footsteps, Varley turned and confronted him.
column6544: He had expected to see Simon, and he stared at Trafford with surprise for a moment, as if too astonished to speak.
column6545: Then he raised his hat, and said, in a voice husky with the dust of the long journey, but with his usual languid manner: “Good-evening.” Trafford raised his hat in response.
column6547: The two men stood looking at each other as two men meeting, perfect strangers and in such a place, must necessarily look; and though neither touched his revolver, each was ready to draw and fire.
column6548: It seemed to Trafford that he had seen the tall, well-knit figure before, but he did not identify it, for the moment, with the horseman Johnson, the driver, had pointed out.
column6549: He was the first to speak; the silence between them was becoming unendurable.
column6550: “I am a stranger here,” he said, “and I have lost my way.” Varley glanced round.
column6551: “That is not at all difficult,” he said.
column6553: “What place is this?” “It is called Raven Claim,” answered Varley.
column6554: As he spoke, it flashed across his mind that Simon had stipulated that only one person should be sent with the ransom.
column6555: No doubt he had Esmeralda concealed somewhere near, and was waiting to see what the presence of two men meant.
column6556: He, Varley, must get rid of this stranger as quickly as possible.
column6557: “May I ask what place you were making for?” he said.
column6559: Varley did not start, but he glanced keenly from under his long lashes at the worn and weary face.
column6561: “You are a long way from there.” “I feared so,” said Trafford.
column6563: “Are you anxious to reach it to-night?” He looked, as he spoke, at the dust-stained figure and pale face.
column6564: “I am very anxious to do so,” said Trafford.
column6565: “I wish to reach it at the first possible moment, and I shall be extremely obliged if you will direct me.” “It is not easy to direct you,” said Varley, “but I will endeavor to do so.
column6566: You appear to have had a long ride?” “I have,” said Trafford, “and I am almost knocked up; but I must reach Three Star to-night.” Varley drew a silver flask from his pocket and held it out.
column6567: “Will you have a drink?” he said.
